script.speaker: David
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm David.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, I want to start with something that has always intrigued me about these chapters. The Bible opens with 'In the beginning God created the heaven and the earth' from Genesis 1:1. But Moses chapter 1 doesn't begin there—what comes before that 'beginning,' and why does it matter so much?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That's a wonderful question, David. It pulls us right into the heart of what God revealed to Moses. Instead of jumping straight to creation, we see Moses in a profound vision, and he asks the Lord directly: 'Be merciful unto thy servant, O God, and tell me concerning this earth, and the inhabitants thereof, and also the heavens' in Moses 1:36.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I love that Moses is so bold in his questioning. So, what does the Lord show him first?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: The Lord reveals Himself and His power. In Moses 1:4, He declares, 'And thou art my son; wherefore look, and I will show thee the workmanship of mine hands.' Then in verse 6, 'And I have a work for thee, Moses, my son.' It's personal and purposeful right from the start.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's striking—'my son' twice. It feels like God is anchoring Moses' identity before anything else.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly. And notice the vision expands: Moses sees 'many lands' and 'worlds without number' in verse 33 and 34. It's overwhelming, preparing him for what's next.

script.speaker: David
script.text: But then, right after this glorious experience, something dramatic shifts. Satan appears in Moses 1:12. Why now, and what does he say?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Satan tries to undermine everything. He says, 'Moses, son of man, worship me' in verse 12. Compare that to God's words—'my son' versus 'son of man.' It's a deliberate counterfeit, confusing Moses' divine worth.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's fascinating. President Nelson taught that the first thing the Lord would make sure we understand is our true identity. This pattern shows up perfectly here—God affirms, Satan attacks.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Yes, look at Moses 1:4, 6 versus 1:12. God speaks with authority and love; Satan with deception. It's a clear difference in how they address our core sense of self.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Help me understand how Moses responds. He doesn't fall for it immediately.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Moses remembers his experience. In verse 13, he says, 'I am a son of God, in the similitude of mine Only Begotten.' He draws on God's prior words to resist. Then he commands Satan, 'Depart hence, Satan' in verse 20.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Powerful. What finally drives Satan away in verses 24-26?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: The Lord intervenes. Moses calls upon God, and the Lord rebukes Satan: 'Depart from before my servant, Satan' in verse 26. It shows we rely on the Lord's power, not our own.

script.speaker: David
script.text: This deepens my view of spiritual experiences—they don't exempt us from temptation, but equip us to overcome it.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Precisely. Now, after this, Moses asks in verse 30, 'Tell me ... why these things are so?' The Lord's response in verses 31-39 is profound.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Yes, verse 39: 'For behold, this is my work and my glory—to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man.' That's the purpose behind it all.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: It ties directly to our place in God's plan. Immortality through the Resurrection, eternal life through covenants and obedience, all centered on Jesus Christ.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I'm intrigued by how Abraham 3 builds on this. Abraham sees a premortal vision that fills in even more.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Absolutely. In Abraham 3:22-28, Abraham learns about intelligences organized before the world was. God says, 'These I will make my rulers' in verse 23, and we were there as spirits.

script.speaker: David
script.text: So, before Moses' creation vision or Abraham's, there's this council. What truths stand out to you there?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Several: We existed as spirits 'before the world was' in verse 22. God chose noble ones, including Abraham in verse 23. And verse 25: 'We will prove them herewith, to see if they will do all things whatsoever the Lord their God shall command them.'

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's a remarkable connection—proving ourselves here links back to Moses' work God has for him.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: It does. Notice how both prophets receive visions framing creation with premortal reality. It's not just 'in the beginning'; it's part of an eternal story.

script.speaker: David
script.text: What strikes me is viewing this from different dispensations. Moses sees it post-vision temptation, Abraham premortally, and us through latter-day revelation.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: From Moses' perspective, it's about resisting counterfeits to fulfill God's work. Abraham grasps the premortal choices leading to earth life. For us, it confirms our divine potential amid modern confusions.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That's a profound way to see it. President Nelson emphasized how thinking about our true identity affects every decision.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Right. In Abraham 3:24-26, it describes the Gods organizing and choosing—the Savior stands out as 'mine Only Begotten.' It mirrors Moses relying on the Only Begotten to overcome Satan.

script.speaker: David
script.text: I hadn't connected those so directly. There's continuity across these revelations.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And think about the cultural context—ancient peoples often viewed gods as distant, but here God speaks intimately as Father to Moses and reveals our premortal nobility to Abraham.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Unlike vague myths, this is precise: intelligences, spirits, proving grounds.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: What many don't realize is how Moses 1 provides context for Genesis. It's the Lord's response to Moses' questions about earth and heavens, setting the stage for creation.

script.speaker: David
script.text: That transforms reading the Old Testament. Now, how does this apply when Satan tempts us with counterfeits today?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Like fake versions of truth—artificial substitutes for real power. Just as Moses recognized and rejected, we can rely on God's declarations of our identity.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And list truths from Abraham 3:22-28 about ourselves and Christ. Why valuable?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: They remind us we chose to come here, to prove faithful. It changes how we face choices, knowing eternal life is the goal.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, tracing this theme of identity from premortal council through Moses' trial to our lives feels like one seamless truth.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: It is. Modern prophets build on it, urging us to make our identity as children of God our primary one.

script.speaker: David
script.text: One more connection: In Moses 1:13, Moses says he's 'in the similitude of mine Only Begotten.' Ties right to Abraham 3's premortal choice of Christ.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Beautiful. It shows Christ's role from before the foundations.

script.speaker: David
script.text: This really deepens my understanding of who we are and God's work.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Mine too. As we ponder these visions, let's consider making a list of choices shaped by this divine identity.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Great idea. What if we reflect on truths from Abraham 3:22-28 in our own lives?

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: It could inspire us to resist temptations by remembering, 'I am a child of God.'

script.speaker: David
script.text: And recognize God's work—to bring us eternal life through Christ.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Exactly. These chapters frame our entire scriptural study beautifully.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Listeners, as you study Moses 1 and Abraham 3, take time to internalize your premortal origins and divine potential. Let it guide your decisions.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: And when doubts come, recall Moses' triumph: rely on the Lord and your true identity.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Thanks, Sarah, for these insights. Until next time, keep studying.
